Graphical abstract The performance of novel mesoporous Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 (x = 0.0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0) catalysts, prepared by hydrothermal method, was investigated for syngas production via methane dry reforming with CO2. Several techniques such as BET, TPR, XRD, CO2-TPD, H2-TPD, TGA/DTA, and TEM were used to characterize the catalysts. The bimetallic species were successfully immobilized by anchoring into the mesoporous hexagonal network of SBA-15. Catalytic experiments conducted at 700 and 800 °C clearly revealed high coking resistance of Co-Ni/Sc-SBA-15 catalyst as demonstrated by TGA/DTA and TEM. Endurance tests undoubtedly demonstrated that the incorporation of Sc in SBA-15 support remarkably enhanced the catalyst performance by transforming the stable carbon deposits into active carbon (inhibition of coke formation); thus achieving excellent stability in dry reforming of methane. Keywords CO2 reforming Co-Ni bimetals Mesoporous SBA-15 Scandium Syngas 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide released by the anthropogenic activities leads to global warming via “greenhouse effect” [1,2]. In addition, methane is another greenhouse gas that has a 25 times higher potential of global warming as compared to CO2 [3]. Growing environmental awareness and regulations prompted the quest for some alternative methods to prevent global warming. CO2 sequestration is a method extensively employed to get rid of CO2, however the effect of buried CO2 on the ecosystem is not certain in the long run [4]. Instead of sequestration, conversion of CO2 is considered more feasible and beneficial from energy and environmental perspectives. In particular, dry reforming of methane (DRM), a growing technology which utilizes these two greenhouse gases and transforms them into a value-added product (syngas composed of hydrogen and carbon monoxide [1,5]) is proposed as a feasible way to obtain synthetic fuels from CO2 and CH4 by Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis [6]. The equimolar composition of syngas (H2/CO = 1) achieved through DRM (Eq. (1)) is the most favorable for FT synthesis. However, H2/CO achieved through DRM is not typically equal to the unity due to some side reactions, for instance, reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction (Eq. (2)), Boudouard reaction (Eq. (3)) and methane decomposition (Eq. (4)) that cause coke deposits on the catalyst surface [7,8]. (1) CH4 + CO2 ↔ 2CO + 2H2 ΔH0 = + 261 kJ mol−1 (2) H2 + CO2 ↔ H2O + CO ΔH0 = + 41 kJ mol−1 (3) 2CO ↔ C + CO2 ΔH0 = −171 kJ mol−1 (4) CH4 ↔ 2H2 + C ΔH0 = + 75 kJ mol−1 Catalyst deactivation due to coking and metal sintering are major challenges that hamper the full maturation of the dry reforming process [9]. Generally, the catalysts employed in dry reforming can be categorized into noble-metal- as well as transition-metal-based catalysts. Noble-metal-based catalysts exhibit an excellent catalytic performance; however, their high cost and less abundance restrict their commercial applicability in the industry [10]. Transition-metal based catalysts, particularly nickel-based catalysts, have been extensively studied due to their relatively high ability of CH bond cleavage, low cost, and abundance. Also Co, which is a well-known oxidation catalyst for carbonaceous matter, has been recently considered in combination with Ni for DRM to improve the stability and activity of the catalysts [2,9]. However, Ni and/or Co undergo agglomeration of active metal nanoparticles and coke-build up on the catalyst surface under severe reaction conditions, resulting in catalyst deterioration. Sintering reduces the surface area of the active metal, and coking may cover the catalyst and subsequently plug the reactor [11]. This limitation can be overcome by immobilizing the active metal particles onto the matrix of the support material. Actually, mesoporous materials offer higher internal surface area and inhibit the growth of metal particles larger than the pore size as a result of confinement effect. Recently, meso-structured oxides such as MCM-41, SBA-15 and HMS have drawn considerable attention as supports. The mesoporous supports enhance the stability and activity as they offer high surface areas which help in the dispersion and stabilization of the Ni particles providing more accessible active Ni centers for the reaction [12]. Zhang et al. examined DRM by employing Ni-SBA-15, Ni-MCM-41, and Ni-KIT-6 catalysts prepared by solid-state grinding method [13]. At 700 °C for 100 h on stream, the CH4 conversion with Ni-SBA-15 was about 78% and H2/CO ratio was very stable and higher than unity. Similarly, Erdogan et al. studied DRM using Ni, Co and Ni-Co catalysts prepared by wet impregnation [14]. Their results showed that the best activity of 73% CH4 and 89% CO2 conversions was obtained using bimetallic 4Ni-1Co/SBA-15 catalyst (Ni/Co = 4/1) operated at 750 °C. The incorporation of Co into SBA-15 supported Ni catalyst decreased coke formation during DRM. On the other hand, Omoregbe et al. investigated the effect of reaction conditions on the catalytic performance of 10%Ni/SBA-15 catalyst for DRM [15]. When this catalyst was operated at PCH4 = PCO2 = 0.2 bar and PN2 = 0.6 bar, the obtained CH4 conversion and H2/CO ratios at 700 °C reached 80% and 0.83 and at 800 °C they increased to 90% and 0.98, respectively. Gálvez et al. evaluated the role of the preparation method on Ni/SBA-15 catalysts: impregnation, precipitation and precipitation in the presence of ascorbic acid as reducing agent [16]. The latter catalyst showed enhanced performance since carbon deposits were mostly on the outer surface of the catalyst particles; a methane conversion of 68% was attained. The resistance of Co-Ni bimetallic catalysts to carbon deposition can be modified by adding noble metals and/or basic oxides (as promoters) as well as rare earth metal oxides like La2O3 and CeO2 (as supports) [17]. Generally, rare earth metal oxides are basic in nature, which facilitates CO2 surface adsorption. Furthermore, rare earth metals enhance catalyst stability by oxidizing the accumulated carbon through their high oxygen storage capacity [6]. For instance, Zhao et al. synthesized Sc promoted and aerogel confined Ni/Al2O3 catalyst using sol–gel method and tested it in DRM at 750 °C over 30 h time on stream [18]. They reported that Sc promotion had enhanced the reactive oxygen species as well as the basic sites contents. It is worth mentioning that Sc-promoted catalysts in comparison with Ni-based catalysts generated more oxygen species and changed the type of deposited carbon on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, an even distribution of Sc and Ni species was achieved and Sc strengthened the interaction between Ni and Al2O3. As a result, Sc-promoted catalysts demonstrated tremendous catalytic activity and better anti-coking performance. Another study employed Sc-promoted Co/TiO2 (P25) catalyst in DRM, synthesized by the incipient wetness impregnation technique [19]. They asserted that Sc incorporation into Co/TiO2 (P25) catalyst significantly enriched its basicity and strengthened metal support interaction, which eventually contributed to the excellent catalytic activity and stability. However, they reported that higher Sc loading led to catalyst deactivation owing to the oxidation of Co metal. The main objective of this research was to synthesize an active and stable catalyst from Co-Ni bimetals supported on Sc-SBA-15 for DRM. The influence of Sc on the activity as well as on the stability of Co-Ni/Sc-SBA-15 was investigated. Furthermore, physicochemical characterization techniques were employed to substantiate our findings. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Diluted HCl solution was used to dissolve template polyethylene glycol-polypropylene block polymer (P123) to prepare the SBA-15. The solution was stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Afterwards a proper quantity of tetraethylorthosilicate was added under continuous stirring for 25 h at room temperature. The resulting suspension was heated at 90 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, the obtained solid SBA-15 was filtered, dried and then calcined at 500 °C for 3 h. SBA-15 was impregnated using incipient wetness method with different amounts of Sc(NO3)3, i.e., 0.0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0% wt/wt). The obtained samples were dried at 120 °C overnight and calcined at 600 °C in air for 4 h. After that, solutions of metal precursors Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O were co-impregnated (incipient wetness) onto the support to obtain the desired catalyst precursors. Then, the catalysts were reduced by 20% H2/Ar gas at 600 °C for 1 h. The catalysts, synthesized without and with Sc in the SBA-15 support, were designated as Co-Ni/SBA-15 and Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA-15 (x = wt%) respectively. The total Co-Ni loading was 10 wt% in the ratio 1:1. 2.2 Catalyst testing The dry reforming tests were performed at atmospheric pressure in a continuous-ﬂow ﬁxed-bed reactor (30 cm long and 9.4 mm inner diameter) using 0.3 g of catalyst. The reaction temperature was measured by a thermocouple positioned in the middle of the catalyst bed. The catalysts were pretreated with H2 at a flow rate of 40 ml/min at 700 °C for 90 min before the reaction. Afterwards, nitrogen at a flow rate of 20 ml/min was used for 20 min to purge the residual H2. Then, the reaction temperature was adjusted while dosing 40 ml/min of N2. A volume ratio of 17/17/6 of (CH4/CO2/N2) was continuously fed during the reaction. A 40 ml/min total feed flow rate and a space velocity of 8000 mL/ (h × gcat) were set. Gaseous products were analyzed by using an online-gas chromatograph (GC-Shimadzu 2014) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Duplicate, in some cases triplicate runs were performed. The variation in conversion was within ± 5%. Error bars were not added to enhance the readability of the figures. In the catalytic test nitrogen was used as an internal standard for calculation of volumetric changes and concentrations of reactants and products. By using test gases that contain hydrogen, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, methane and nitrogen in different concentrations the GC response factors were determined. Carbon balance was calculated based on the molar flow rates of products and reactants (in terms of carbon atoms) and was found to be in the range of 96–102% throughout all runs. 2.3 Catalyst characterization A Panalytical X'Pert Pro diffractometer having a RTMS detector (X’Celerator) was used to register the XRD patterns. Automatic divergence slits and Cu Kα1/2 1/a2 radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) was applied. Scan mode: continuous; step range: 5–80° 2θ; step size: 0.0167° and counting time: 25 s/step. Cu beta-radiation was omitted by using nickel filter foil. Cu K alpha2 radiation was subtracted arithmetically using the Panalytical HighScore Plus software package. Peak positions and profiles were tailored to Pseudo-Voigt function using the WinXPow software package (Stoe). Phase documentation was accomplished by using the PDF-2 database of the International Center of Diffraction Data (ICDD). The speciﬁc surface area of the fresh and spent catalysts was determined by means of a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 surface area and porosity analyzer at −196 °C from N2 adsorption–desorption data. In the analysis, 0.2–0.3 g of sample was used. Samples were degassed at 200 °C for 2 h to remove adsorbed gases or moisture from the catalyst surface. BJH method was used to calculate the pore size distribution from the desorption branch of the nitrogen isotherm. Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 unit was employed to perform temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) measurements. In the case of H2-TPR, a sample weight of 0.07 g was heated at the rate of 10 K/min to 900 °C in a gas mixture of H2/Ar (10/90 vol%) with a ﬂow rate of 40 ml/min. Prior to TPR experiments, the materials were heated at 200 °C for 1 h in an inert atmosphere, then the temperature was decreased to room temperature. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to follow the H2 consumption. Similarly, in the case of temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) measurements, weakly bound species absorbed on the sample were first removed by flowing helium at 200 °C for 1 h. Later, the adsorption of CO2 was performed at 50 °C for half an hour while dosing a mixture of CO2/He (10/90 vol%) at a ﬂow rate of 30 ml/min. Ultimately, TCD measured the desorption signal of CO2 during the gradual temperature rise to 800 °C at a rate of 10 K/min. To evaluate metal surface area (MSA) and metal dispersion (DMe) of the investigated catalysts, H2-TPD measurements in the range of 25–650 °C (β = 10 °C/min) were carried out at atmospheric pressure in a home-made continuous-flow apparatus by using a linear quartz micro-reactor (i.d., 4 mm) flowing Ar as carrier gas at 50 STP cm3/min. Before measurements, catalyst sample (ca. 30 mg) was reduced for half-an hour in flowing of H2 (25 STP cm3/min) at 700 °C. Thereafter, the sample was cooled under H2 atmosphere to room temperature and then purged by the carrier stream until baseline stabilization (≈30 min). Assuming a chemisorption stoichiometry H2:Mesurf = 1:2 and a spherical shape of the metal particle, the following equations were applied: (5) MSA (m2/gcat) = 2·XH2·NAv/σMe (6) DMe (%) = 200·XH2·WMe/(CMe/100) where “XH2” is the H2 uptake (mol/gcat), “NAv” is the Avogadro’s number, “σMe” represents the average number of surface atoms (considering 1.54 × 1019 and 1.51 × 1019 at/m2, for Ni and Co respectively) [20], “WMe” is the average atomic weight of Ni and Co metals, while “CMe” is their cumulative metal loading (wt %). EXSTAR SII TG/DTA 7300 (Thermo-gravimetric/Differential) analyzer was used with air atmosphere to compute the amount of carbon deposited on the spent catalysts. For this analysis 10–20 mg of sample were heated from room temperature up to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 K/min. JEM-ARM200 F (JEOL, Corrector: CEOS) electron microscope was used at 200 kV with an aberration-corrected. JED-2300 (JEOL) energy-dispersive X-ray-spectrometer (EDXS) comes along with the microscope for chemical analysis. The aberration-adjusted STEM imaging of High-Angle Annular Dark Field (HAADF) and Annular Bright Field (ABF) were accomplished in this way. HAADF and ABF both were done with a spot size of approximately 0.1 nm, a convergence angle of 30-36° and collection semi-angles for HAADF and ABF of 90–170 mrad and 11–22 mrad, respectively. The fresh and spent solid samples were laid in the microscope of the TEM without any pretreatment on a holey carbon supported Cu-grid (mesh 300). A high resolution camera provided with dedicated ITEM software was used for the PSD evaluation. The number of particles considered for each sample was about 800-1000. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 EDX and phase analysis (XRD) In the supporting information, the EDX analysis results of catalysts containing 5%Co-5%Ni/2.5%Sc-SBA-15 and 5%Co-5%Ni/5%Sc-SBA-15 are displayed in Figs. S1 and S2 respectively. The results show a unity ratio of Co:Ni in both catalysts, while the amount of Sc in the 2.5% Sc-SBA-15 catalyst was half of that in 5% Sc-SBA-15 catalyst. Thus the result confirms the attainment of the desired composition of catalysts for this study. Fig. 1 shows the diffraction patterns of Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 (x = 0.0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0) and pure SBA-15. The wider diffraction peak observed at 2θ = 15–30° can be ascribed to amorphous SiO2 frameworks of SBA-15 (ICDD PDF No. 29-00). In addition, no noticeable reflections of Sc2O3 phase were observed in the XRD pattern. It is assumed that Sc was highly dispersed on Co-Ni/SBA-15 catalyst surface. The diffraction reflections at 2θ = 37.1°, 43.1°, 62.6°, and 75.0° are designated to NiO crystalline phase (PDF No. 01-071-4750). The reflections associated with NiCo2O4 (PDF No. 01-073-1702) or CoCo2O4 (PDF No. 01-080-1544) were at 2θ = 31.1°, 36.6°, 44.6°, 58.9 and 64.6°. Moreover, it is hard to differentiate between Co-Ni or Co spinel phases as they crystallize in a cubic unit cell possessing comparable lattice constants. A prominent feature in the XRD patterns is the decrease in the NiO reflex intensities with increasing Sc content, indicating the size reduction of Co and/or Ni oxide crystallites after Sc addition which contributed to higher catalytic activity [21]. 3.1.2 Textural properties (BET) The surface texture was analyzed by employing the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. Fig. 2 displays nitrogen sorption isotherms of the fresh Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 (x = 0.0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0) catalysts and pure SBA-15 support, whereas specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter are listed in Table 1 . As per the IUPAC classification, the bare support and the catalysts demonstrated type IV isotherm with an H1-type hysteresis loop (P/P0) = 0.45-0.75, implying the occurrence of cylindrically shaped pores with an ordered mesoporous framework. This indicates also that after the addition of Co, Ni and Sc, the meso-structure of the catalysts was preserved. Table 1 displays the decline of BET surface area and pore volume due to Ni and Co species impregnated to SBA-15. Bare SBA-15 showed surface area, pore size, and pore volume of 819 m2/g, 5.4 nm, and 0.75 cm3/g respectively. On impregnating Co and Ni a loss of 43% of the surface area was observed due to Co and Ni metallic species migrating into the channels and settling on the surface of SBA-15. Inversely, it is worth stating that the addition of Sc to Ni-Co/SBA-15 has appreciably changed the textural properties of the catalyst. This might be due to the addition of low Sc content that enters the SiO2 and widen slightly the pores. On increasing the Sc content the pores are plugged causing a decrease in surface area which can be observed in 10% Sc. The larger pore volume and specific surface area assist in the dispersion of metallic species over the support. In contrast, the poor dispersion and the partial clogging of mesopores with larger active metal species (Sc > 2.5 wt%) more likely cause the smaller volume in case of Ni-Co/SBA-15 catalyst without Sc addition. 3.1.3 Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) Reducibility of Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 (x = 0.0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0) catalysts was investigated by TPR analysis (see Fig. 3 ). As found in the literature, Ni supported on SBA-15 shows three peaks below 400 °C, 500–600 °C and above 600 °C which correspond to weak, middle and strong interaction [22–25]. However, in our case Ni/SBA-15 showed only two peaks for weak and middle interaction with the support. Co/SBA-15 is reduced between 700–800 °C due to a strong interaction with support and showed also two small peaks below 400 °C for the reduction of large crystals of Co3O4 to Co° via CoO formation oxides [25–27]. In case of Co-Ni/SBA-15, the sharp reduction peak at 270 °C may be attributed to the reduction of NiCo2O4 forming Co-Ni alloy. On the other hand, broadening of the reduction peak in the high-temperature zone (reduction of Co oxide in a strong interaction with the support) and shift toward lower temperature was observed which could be due to Co-Ni strong interaction with SBA-15 as proposed by Zhang et al [28]. The TPR profiles of the Sc promoted catalysts can be classified into two key reduction zones: below 400 °C and above 400 °C [29]. The reduction peaks associated with the first zone can be ascribed to the reduction of oxide species located on the external surface of the mesoporous hexagonal framework, which have a weak interaction with the support. After Sc addition to Co-Ni/SBA-15, the low temperature peak (above 200 °C) slightly shifted to a higher temperature due to Ni and/or Co oxides in solid solution with Sc2O3 (bulk reduction). In addition, a small peak appeared below 200 °C which might be due to the reduction of surface oxide species. This peak appeared above 2.5% Sc2O3 load. Conversely, the high reduction temperature peak (above 600 °C) remained unchanged and is not affected by Sc2O3 addition indicating the formation of stable Co-Ni species that are in the matrix of SBA-15. The amount of hydrogen consumption and the degree of reduction using Ni2+ and Co3+ percentage as base value was also calculated (Table 2 ) and increased upon addition of Sc2O3. In the presence of Sc2O3 the oxygen located within the bulk or subsurface can migrate to the surface after the consumption of surface oxygen, corresponding to the relatively higher oxygen mobility [30,31]. This also agrees with the highest amount of H2 uptake found for Co-Ni/5%Sc-SBA-15 (Table 2). However, when the Sc loading was increased to 7.5 or 10 wt%, TPR profiles revealed that the samples had ample surface oxygen species, however, the amount of H2 uptake for these catalysts was less than that of catalyst containing 5% Sc loading. 3.1.4 Temperature programmed desorption (CO2 -TPD) and (H2- TPD) The basic properties of Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 (x = 0.0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10) catalysts were estimated by CO2-TPD measurements (see profiles in Fig. 4 and Table 3 ). Generally, in TPD, the basicity is reported with reference to the temperature range where the adsorbate CO2is desorbed from the basic sites. Usually, the strength of basic sites is categorized as weak, medium, strong and very strong for temperatures of (<200 °C), (200–400 °C), (400–650 °C) and (>650 °C) respectively [32]. In fact, the peak area of Co-Ni/5.0%Sc-SBA–15 and Co-Ni/10.0%Sc-SBA–15 was larger than that of Co-Ni/SBA–15. Loading 5.0% and 10% Sc had considerably raised the basicity of Co-Ni/SBA–15 by 32% and 37%, respectively. Generally, addition of Sc increases the capacity for CO2 adsorption that affects catalyst activity. This behavior was noticed by Zhao et al [18]. Based on these results, it is plausible to infer that incorporation of Sc represents a valid option for significantly increasing the basicity of catalyst. H2-TPD was done in order to determine the metal particle dispersion. As it is possible to observe from Table 4 the metal dispersion was found to be in the range of 7.9–15.7%. The addition of Sc significantly enhances the hydrogen uptake, and dispersion leading to a maximum value of 133.8μmol/gcat over the Co-Ni/5%Sc-SBA-15 sample and accounting for a metal surface area and dispersion of 10.6 m2/gcat and 15.7% respectively. However, the storage capacity clearly decreases at a higher loading of scandium promoter, as evidenced from the minor H2 uptake in the Co-Ni/10%Sc-SBA-15 sample (82.6 μmol/gcat), which reflects a drop both in MSA (6.5 m2/gcat) and in metal dispersion (9.7%). 3.1.5 TEM of fresh catalysts TEM analyses of reduced 5%Sc-SBA-15, Co-Ni/SBA–15 and Co-Ni/5%Sc-SBA–15 catalysts were conducted to investigate the structure, morphology and distribution of bimetallic Co-Ni particles. As shown in Fig. 5 , the morphological evolution of the fresh catalysts presents a highly ordered, periodic and three-dimensional network of SBA-15. As it can be observed from the images (a) and (b) of reduced 5%Sc-SBA-15, Sc roundly distributes on the SBA-15 surface and preferably deposits at the edges. The dimension of Sc particles ranges from 20 to 40 nm and the shape is not spherical. After the addition of Co and Ni (see (c), (d) images) both types of the metallic particles are randomly distributed on SBA surface. Indistinguishable Ni and Co metallic particles of 40–60 nm were distributed on the external surface of the SBA-15 support. However, it is interesting to observe (see image (e) of Co-Ni/5.0%Sc-SBA–15) that very small particles, yet not identified, were deposited inside the well-ordered mesoporous hexagonal channels of SBA-15. Fig. 5 clearly shows a significant difference between the Ni-Co catalysts supported on SBA-15 without and with Sc. In case of SBA-15 support without Sc, the Ni-Co particles are quite large (about 200 nm) and are not present inside the SBA-15 channels. To the contrary, using SBA-15 containing Sc, the Ni-Co particles are smaller in size (5–40 nm) and a significant part of particles also enters the channels giving rise to a distribution characterized by nano-sized level (Fig. 6 ). 3.2 Catalytic activity and stability The activities of Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 (x = 0.0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, 10.0) catalysts operated at 700 °C and 800 °C over a period of 400 min in DRM are displayed in Figs. 7 and 8 . The role of Sc modifier on the catalytic performance of Co-Ni/SBA–15 in terms of H2/CO ratio, H2 selectivity and deactivation factor at 700 °C reaction temperature for the period of 400 min is illustrated in Fig. 9 . As shown in Fig. 7, at 700 °C, the initial CH4 conversion of unmodified catalyst Co-Ni/SBA–15 was about 55%, however, as the time progressed, it dropped to 48% after 400 min; likewise, CO2 conversion dropped from 69% to 61% over the same period. This decline in activity may be attributed to the development of stable carbon deposits over the surface of the bimetallic species as validated by TEM and TGA/DTA of spent catalyst (as discussed below) as depicted by BET surface area of the spent Co-Ni/SBA–15 catalyst (Table 1). Consequently, this decreased the catalytic activity as illustrated by the highest deactivation factor (Fig. 9). In contrast, upon Sc doping, the activity of catalysts increased throughout the specified period. It was observed that the activity rises as Sc is incorporated into Co-Ni/SBA-15, whereas the deactivation factor gradually decreases (Fig. 9). Obviously, the influence of Sc doping becomes insignificant beyond 5.0% Sc loading, because the activity, H2 selectivity, H2/CO ratio and deactivation factor were more or less comparable for the rest of the catalysts. In fact, the stagnation in activity beyond a certain Sc loading, may be associated with the partial coverage of the active sites by Sc [33]. Thus, the addition of 5.0% Sc to Co-Ni/SBA–15 increased CH4 conversion by 25% and CO2 conversion by 14% at 700 °C reaction temperature. Interestingly, the H2/CO ratio approached unity with Sc incorporation compared to the unpromoted catalyst. The H2/CO ratio less than unity may be attributed to the presence of the RWGS reaction (Eq. (2)), which consumed H2 and produced CO. When the temperature was raised to 800 °C (Fig. 8), the rise in CH4 and CO2 conversions displayed similar trends as those at 700 °C (Fig. 7). It is worthy to mention that the undoped Co-Ni/SBA–15 catalyst deactivated, while Sc-doped catalysts remained stable over the investigated period. The CO2 conversion was appreciably higher in comparison with CH4 conversion for all catalysts. The higher CO2 conversion is linked to RWGS reaction. The bare Co-Ni/SBA-15 catalyst showed the highest deactivation whereas with Sc loading, the deactivation decreased and a stable catalyst operation was established above a Sc loading of 5 wt% (Fig. 9). Another recent study conducted by Xin et al. employed 10% bimetallic (Ni-Co)/SBA-15 catalyst with varying mass ratios of the active metals for DRM [25]. The optimum result was obtained using 9%Ni-1%Co/SBA-15 catalyst at 800 °C, giving 87% CH4 conversion with no significant coke deposition, and a H2/CO molar ratio close to unity over 50 h on stream. It is obvious that the performance of 9%Ni-1%Co/SBA-15 catalyst treated at 800 °C was less than that in the present study that gave CH4 conversions above 90% (see Fig. 8), which implies that Sc doping had enhanced the catalytic performance. Since Co-Ni/5%Sc-SBA–15 gave the highest CH4 and CO2 conversions and H2 selectivity, Co-Ni/5.0%Sc-SBA-15 was opted as an optimal catalyst for the long-term tests at 700 °C and 800 °C under similar conditions over a period of 40 h (Fig. 10 ). The catalyst exhibited excellent stability at 800 °C, whereas little decline in activity was observed at 700 °C. In fact, Co-Ni/5.0%Sc-SBA–15 presented remarkable stability due to the suppression of carbon deposition and resistance against sintering. The CH4 turnover frequency for the catalysts was calculated as shown in Table 4 and found to be in the range of 409.7–651.7 and 525.1–960.3 h−1 at reaction temperatures 700 and 800 °C, respectively. It is noticed although the surface area and in turn also the dispersion of metal particles decreased with increasing Sc content above 5%, however, the turnover frequency of both 7.5 and 10% Sc increased which is unexpected. This means on the high loading although the addition of Sc plugged and decreased the number of active sites, it improved their characteristics. A plausible explanation of this relates to the increase of basicity as found from TPD-CO2 (see Table 3) with the addition of more Sc; this increase facilitated the adsorption of CO2 causing more CH4 to be converted with gasification of the carbon. The key features of Sc incorporation into the catalyst include: firstly; stabilizing the Ni particle and avoiding agglomeration via metal-support interaction as has been seen from TEM and TPR studies (a slight shift in the reduction temperature). Secondly, enhancing the basicity of the catalysts as has been demonstrated by TPD-CO2. It is well known that catalysts with high basicity contribute more effectively to CO2 adsorption and its dissociation, which in turn helps to gasify the intermediate carbon on the catalyst surface and to improve the coking resistance of the catalyst [24,25]. Thirdly, enriching the catalyst surface with oxygen species that are reduced at relatively low temperature between 150 and 300 °C as has been demonstrated by TPR [18,34]. The oxygen vacancies are recognized as a source for reactant adsorption and activation. Furthermore, they are also responsible for providing the pathways for oxygen mobility through the bulk lattice, which is regarded as an oxygen reservoir that stores and releases it for surface reaction. The active surface oxygen species react with the deposited carbon and suppress the coke accumulation on the catalyst surface, leading to remarkable catalytic stability. However, the deficiency of lattice oxygen or inadequate oxygen mobility would cause the accumulation of carbon deposits [30]. 3.2.1 TEM of spent catalyst It is well known that CO2 reforming is strongly affected by carbon accumulation that deactivates the catalyst. Therefore, in order to understand the carbon deposition over the catalyst surface, TEM of spent catalysts was performed and the results are illustrated in Figs. 11–13 . With regard to the catalysts used at 700 °C, Figs. 11 and 12 clearly present that coke coverage of the surface is prevalent in the absence of Sc (Fig. 11a) [35]; this carbon encapsulates and deactivates the metal particles which are exposed on the surface of the SBA. In addition, in the absence of Sc, the bimetallic particles agglomerated (Fig. 11b). On the other hand, the Sc-containing catalyst is characterized by the presence of only filamentous coke. The size of such filaments (multiwall nanotubes) is known to be related to the size of the starting metal particles. The bimetallic particles were almost evenly dispersed after 400 min of catalytic activity (Fig. 12c and d) with an average particle diameter of 11 nm (Fig. 6b). Therefore, the catalytic activity of the modified catalyst remained stable with time on stream. Nevertheless, when the Sc loading was further increased to 10%, a cluster of multi-walled carbon nanofibers was created whilst the bimetallic particles were located at the tip of carbon nanofibers (Fig. 12f). Fig. 13 clearly shows that at 800 °C the formation of coke is almost suppressed, but sintering of the Ni-Co superficial metal is predominant probably due to the high reaction temperature. Sintering is more evident from Fig. 13d. Actually, the bimetallic particles located on the external surface started losing their position and agglomerated into bigger particles. In contrast, the metal particles confined inside the hexagonal mesopores had little prospects of sintering because of the steric hindrance [32]. 3.2.2 Thermal analysis of spent catalysts (TGA/DTA) DTA and TGA were employed to quantify the amount and nature of accumulated carbon on spent Co-Ni/SBA–15 and Co-Ni/5.0%Sc-SBA–15 catalysts that were operated at 700 and 800 °C over different time on stream (Fig. 14 ). Depending on the carbon oxidation temperatures, two main regions are identified on the DTA profile: the peaks below 500 °C are ascribed to the oxidation of highly reactive amorphous carbon, whereas the peaks above 500 °C signify the oxidation of graphitic carbon species [36–38]. From DTA profile (Fig. 14b) it can be seen that Co-Ni/SBA–15 shows both peaks, confirming the presence of amorphous as well as graphitic carbon, respectively. It is worth noticing that the ﬁrst peak shared 8%, while the second peak as much as 92% of the total mass of carbon (TGA). It implies that Co-Ni/-SBA–15 has got the highest inert carbon build-up, which is prone to catalyst deactivation. However, upon Sc addition, the first peak and a small shoulder appeared at a lower temperature, while the second peak completely vanished. Furthermore, first peak shifted towards a lower temperature, which specifies the influence of Sc in catalyzing the oxidation of accumulated carbon and the development of less ordered carbon structures [39]. When the DRM temperature with the promoted catalyst was raised to 800 °C, the combustion peaks were shifted to a slightly higher temperature. The peak shift may be associated with subsequent changes in the carbon structure [40]; however, in our investigation, no graphitic carbon formation appeared even at higher temperature. When the Sc-modified catalyst was tested for a long-term stability at 700 °C, an additional oxidation peak, corresponding to the graphitic carbon, appeared. The first and the second peaks contributed 74% and 26% to the total mass of accumulated carbon (TGA), respectively. Thus, the amount of graphitic carbon in the case of Sc-modified catalyst even after 40 h was far less than that for the catalyst without Sc, i.e, (Co-Ni/SBA-15). The TGA patterns visualize that carbon content was highest with Co-Ni/5.0%Sc-SBA-15. However, DTA revealed that the incorporation of Sc had transformed the inert carbon into reactive carbon that is easily oxidized into CO in the case of Co-Ni/5.0%Sc-SBA–15 catalyst. These findings of TGA/DTA are in good agreement with TEM of spent catalysts. In conclusion it is evident from the TEM images (Fig. 11) and DTA profile (Fig. 14) that the carbon was almost vanished by the incorporation of Sc to Co-Ni/SBA-15. Interestingly, it is also obvious from Fig. 15 and Table 1 that Co-Ni/5%Sc-SBA-15 catalyst maintained its mesoporous structure and there was not sudden decline in the surface area activity even after 40 h., which implies that Sc incorporation has contributed to the resistance against sintering. The results of the present work show enhancement in performance as compared with the literature [12–14, 36, 40]. 4 Conclusions Novel Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 mesoporous catalysts were synthesized by incipient-wetness impregnating hydrothermally prepared SBA-15 with 5% Co, 5% Ni and various loadings of Sc and tested in DRM. Bimetallic species of Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 were successfully immobilized inside the hexagonal mesoporous framework, which restricted their mobility and subsequently prevented sintering even at higher reaction temperature (700 and 800 °C). Promoting the SBA-15 with Sc generated well-dispersed bimetallic species and high surface area. Moreover, Sc incorporation in Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 catalysts ensured a higher surface basicity and consequently higher surface oxygen coverage. As a consequence, the graphitic carbon formation was minimized while amorphous carbon was promptly gasified. In addition, the incorporation of Sc contributed to activation as well as reduction of CO2 with benefits in terms of conversion and coke formation inhibition. In fact, at 700 °C, the addition of Sc to Co-Ni/SBA–15 led to a rise in CH4 conversion by 25% and CO2 conversion by 14% and a reduction of coke of 25% with respect to unpromoted Ni-Co/SBA15 catalyst. On using Sc promoted catalysts at 800 °C, the coke formation rate became very low and catalyst activity remained stable. In general, it can be concluded that Sc addition enhanced the properties of the active centers which in turn increased the CH4 turnover frequency by increasing the basicity which assisted in more CO2 adsorption and more CH4 conversion. Moreover, Sc doping is effective in suppressing coke deposition by promptly oxidizing the accumulated carbon without allowing the formation of stable graphitic coke. The 5%Sc catalyst is active and stable over 40 h on stream at 800 °C but probably it’s not the optimum, and it would be interesting to investigate the stability of both 5% and 10%Sc at more sever conditions. coredata.dc:description: The performance of novel mesoporous Co-Ni/x%Sc-SBA–15 (x = 0.0, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0) catalysts, prepared by hydrothermal method, was investigated for syngas production via methane dry reforming with CO2. Several techniques such as BET, TPR, XRD, CO2-TPD, H2-TPD, TGA/DTA, and TEM were used to characterize the catalysts. The bimetallic species were successfully immobilized by anchoring into the mesoporous hexagonal network of SBA-15. Catalytic experiments conducted at 700 and 800 °C clearly revealed high coking resistance of Co-Ni/Sc-SBA-15 catalyst as demonstrated by TGA/DTA and TEM. Endurance tests undoubtedly demonstrated that the incorporation of Sc in SBA-15 support remarkably enhanced the catalyst performance by transforming the stable carbon deposits into active carbon (inhibition of coke formation); thus achieving excellent stability in dry reforming of methane.
coredata.dc:title: Evaluation of Co-Ni/Sc-SBA–15 as a novel coke resistant catalyst for syngas production via CO2 reforming of methane
